defs.docs: SSD1306 OLED display driver

attributes.value: ! The driver must be initialised by passing an I2C or SPI interface peripheral to the [`Builder`],
! which will in turn create a driver instance in a particular mode. By default, the builder
! returns a [`RawMode`] instance which isn't very useful by itself. You can coerce the driver
! into a more useful mode by calling `into()` and defining the type you want to coerce to. For
! example, to initialise the display with an I2C interface and [`GraphicsMode`], you would do
! // Configure an I2C interface on the target device; below line shown as example only
! There is also [`TerminalMode`] which allows drawing of characters to the display without
! // Configure an I2C interface on the target device; below line shown as example only
! It's possible to customise the driver to suit your display/application. Take a look at the
! ## Write text to the display without a framebuffer
! // Spam some characters to the display
! ## Draw some text to the display

defs.name: builder
defs.docs: Interface factory

attributes.value: ! This is the easiest way to create a driver instance, with the ability to set various parameters of the driver.
! To finish the builder and produce a connected display interface, call `.connect_i2c(i2c)` or
! `.connect_spi(spi, dc)`. The builder will be consumed into a
! [`mode::RawMode`](../mode/raw/struct.RawMode.html) object which can be coerced into a richer
! Connect over SPI with default rotation (0 deg) and size (128x64):
! Connect over I2C, changing lots of options
! The above examples will produce a [RawMode](../mode/raw/struct.RawMode.html) instance
! by default. You need to coerce them into a mode by specifying a type on assignment. For

defs.docs:
Set the I2C address to use. Defaults to 0x3C which is the most common address.
 The other address specified in the datasheet is 0x3D. Ignored when using SPI interface.

attributes.value: / Set the I2C address to use. Defaults to 0x3C which is the most common address.

defs.name: with_rotation
defs.docs:
Set the rotation of the display to one of four values. Defaults to no rotation. Note that
 90º and 270º rotations are not supported by
 [`TerminalMode`](../mode/terminal/struct.TerminalMode.html).

-> DisplayMode<RawMode<I2cInterface<I2C>>> where
I2C: hal::blocking::i2c::Write<Error = CommE>
defs.docs: Finish the builder and use I2C to communicate with the display

defs.name: connect_spi
defs.value:
pub fn connect_spi<SPI, DC, CommE, PinE>(&Self, SPI, DC)
-> DisplayMode<RawMode<SpiInterface<SPI, DC>>> where
SPI: hal::blocking::spi::Transfer<u8, Error = CommE> +
hal::blocking::spi::Write<u8, Error = CommE>, DC: OutputPin<Error = PinE>

defs.name: interface
defs.docs: SSD1306 Communication Interface (I2C/SPI)

attributes.value: ! These are the two supported interfaces for communicating with the display. They're used by the
! The types that these interfaces define are quite lengthy, so it is recommended that you create
! a type alias. Here's an example for the I2C1 on an STM32F103xx:
! Here's one for SPI1 on an STM32F103xx:
! # use stm32f1xx_hal::gpio::{Alternate, Floating, Input, Output, PushPull};

defs.name: set_pixel
defs.value: pub fn set_pixel(&mut Self, u32, u32, u8)
defs.docs:
Turn a pixel on or off. A non-zero `value` is treated as on, `0` as off. If the X and Y
 coordinates are out of the bounds of the display, this method call is a noop.

attributes.value: / Turn a pixel on or off. A non-zero `value` is treated as on, `0` as off. If the X and Y
/ coordinates are out of the bounds of the display, this method call is a noop.

defs.name: terminal
defs.docs: Unbuffered terminal display mode

attributes.value: ! This mode uses the 7x7 pixel [MarioChrome](https://github.com/techninja/MarioChron/) font to
! draw characters to the display without needing a framebuffer. It will write characters from top
! left to bottom right in an 8x8 pixel grid, restarting at the top left of the display once full.
! The display itself takes care of wrapping lines.

Get the current cursor position, in character coordinates.
 This is the (column, row) that the next character will be written to.

defs.name: set_draw_area
defs.value: pub fn set_draw_area(&mut Self, (u8, u8), (u8, u8)) -> Result<(), DI::Error>
defs.docs:
Set the position in the framebuffer of the display limiting where any sent data should be
 drawn. This method can be used for changing the affected area on the screen as well
 as (re-)setting the start point of the next `draw` call.
 Only works in Horizontal or Vertical addressing mode

attributes.value: / Set the position in the framebuffer of the display limiting where any sent data should be
/ drawn. This method can be used for changing the affected area on the screen as well
/ as (re-)setting the start point of the next `draw` call.
/ Only works in Horizontal or Vertical addressing mode

defs.name: set_column
defs.value: pub fn set_column(&mut Self, u8) -> Result<(), DI::Error>
defs.docs:
Set the column address in the framebuffer of the display where any sent data should be
 drawn.
 Only works in Page addressing mode.

attributes.value: / Set the column address in the framebuffer of the display where any sent data should be
/ Only works in Page addressing mode.

defs.name: set_row
defs.value: pub fn set_row(&mut Self, u8) -> Result<(), DI::Error>
defs.docs:
Set the page address (row 8px high) in the framebuffer of the display where any sent data
 should be drawn.
 Note that the parameter is in pixels, but the page will be set to the start of the 8px
 row which contains the passed-in row.
 Only works in Page addressing mode.

attributes.value: / Set the page address (row 8px high) in the framebuffer of the display where any sent data
/ Note that the parameter is in pixels, but the page will be set to the start of the 8px
/ row which contains the passed-in row.
/ Only works in Page addressing mode.

defs.name: draw
defs.value: pub fn draw(&mut Self, &[u8]) -> Result<(), DI::Error>
defs.docs:
Send the data to the display for drawing at the current position in the framebuffer
 and advance the position accordingly. Cf. `set_draw_area` to modify the area affected by
 this method in horizontal / vertical mode.

attributes.value: / Send the data to the display for drawing at the current position in the framebuffer
/ and advance the position accordingly. Cf. `set_draw_area` to modify the area affected by
/ this method in horizontal / vertical mode.
